com.panasonic.toughpad.android.api.serial

Interface SerialPort


  • public interface SerialPort
    SerialPort represents a serial communication device.

    • Method Detail

      • enable

        void enable(int baudRate,
            int dataSize,
            int parityMode,
            int stopBits,
            int flowControl)
     throws java.io.IOException
        Enables (connects) the serial port for use. If dataSize is DATASIZE_5 and stopBits is STOPBITS_2, then the stop bits is set to 1.5. Once the serial port has been enabled, no other application can communicate with the serial port.
        Parameters:
        baudRate - The baud rate to use. See the BAUDRATE_*** constants.
        dataSize - The data size to use. See the DATASIZE_*** constants. Note that DATASIZE_5 and DATASIZE_6 are not supported for FTDI-based converters.
        parityMode - The parity mode to use. See the PARITY_*** constants.
        stopBits - The stop bits to use. See the STOPBITS_*** constants.
        flowControl - The flow control method to use. See the FLOWCONTROL_*** constants. Note that FLOWCONTROL_XON_XOFF is not supported for Prolific-based converters.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If the port could not be enabled, for example, if its already in use by another application.
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - If the serial port is already enabled.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If any of the arguments are not in the range specified.
        See Also:
        isEnabled(), disable()

      • isEnabled

        boolean isEnabled()
        Returns:
        True if serial port is enabled for use, false otherwise.
        See Also:
        enable(int, int, int, int, int), disable()

      • getInputStream

        java.io.InputStream getInputStream()
        Retrieve an input stream to communicate with the device. When the serial port has been closed or physically disconnected, the InputStream.read(byte[], int, int) method will return -1, indicating an EOF (end of file) condition. Otherwise, it will block until bytes are available and then read them.
        Returns:
        The input stream to receive data from the serial device.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - If the serial port is not enabled.

      • getOutputStream

        java.io.OutputStream getOutputStream()
        Returns:
        The output stream to send data to the serial device.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - If the serial port is not enabled.

      • getDeviceName

        java.lang.String getDeviceName()
        Returns:
        The name of the serial port device. This varies by implementation. In most cases it will return the device node name, such as "ttyUSBX" where X is a number from 0 - 254.

      • disable

        void disable()
        Disables (disconnects) the serial port, allowing other applications to use it. This will automatically close the input/output streams retrieved with getInputStream() and getOutputStream().
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - If the serial port is not enabled.
